Detailed Description

This class represents a keyboard widget.

The Florence class is a QGraphicsView and inherits QWidget. Florence renders a visually appealing keyboard inside a QWidget that can be controlled by the application. Florence provides a way to input text in another text edit widget.

The keyboard is optimized for touch input. Keys are magnified when touched and a signal is emitted on touch end. The signal is also sent when keys are held down for longer than 1 second. The keys are auto repeated every 0.2 second for as long as they are held down.

One can show and hide the keyboard with the show() and hide() slots (inherited from QWidget), which can be connected to the focusInEvent() and focusOutEvent() methods of the target input widget. Florence sends an inputText() signals to input text in the target widget. The backspace(), enter(), tab() and leftTab() signals are sent when their respective keys are activated.

You can find an example of target widget class here: lineedit.h. Class implementation: lineedit.cpp.

The keymap, the layout and the style can be read from an xml file by calling the setKeymap(), setLayout() and setStyle() member functions, respectively. The style is what dictates the visual appearance of the keyboard. It defines the shape of the keys and symbols. The layout defines the how the keys are disposed on the keyboard. The keymap assigns a symbol value to each key that is language dependant. The default files are included in a binary resource inside the library. On some platforms, if Florence is compiled as a static library and you use the default file (by not calling the functions above), it may be necessary to call the Q_INIT_RESOURCE(florence_qt) macro for Florence to display something.

Here is an code example for instantiating Florence:

 Florence *f = new Florence( this );
 f->setLayout( "florence.layout" );
 f->setStyle( "florence.style" );
 f->setKeymap( "us.xml" );

 LineEdit l = new LineEdit( this );
 QObject::connect( f, SIGNAL(inputText(QString)), l, SLOT(insertText(QString)) );
 QObject::connect( f, SIGNAL(backspace()), l, SLOT(backSpace()) );
 f->setFocusProxy( l );

Note the setFocusProxy makes sure Florence doesn't steal the keyboard focus from the input widget so it keeps the cursor displayed.

Member Function Documentation

Florence::backspace (  )  [signal]

Back space signal.

This signal is emitted when the BackSpace key has been activated. It should be connected to the slot that deletes the character to the left of the text cursor in the target widget.

Florence::enter (  )  [signal]

Return signal.

This signal is emitted when the Return key has been activated. It can be used to hide the keyboard, or input a carriage return, depending on the context.

Florence::inputText ( QString  text  )  [signal]

Input text signal.

This signal is emitted when a key that should input text is activated. It should be connected to the slot that inserts text in the target widget.

Parameters:
text The text value of the key that has been activated.

Florence::leftTab (  )  [signal]

Left tab signal.

This signal is emitted when the Left tab key has been activated. This can be used to move the focus to the previous widget, or to unindent text in the target widget.

Florence::setColor ( enum StyleItem::style_colours  color,
QString  value 
)

Changes a style color.

Sets the color of a style element. The color is a string that represents the value of the color in one of those format:

  • #RGB ( #0FF )
  • #RRGGBB ( #00FFFF )
  • #RRRRGGGGBBBB ( #0000FFFFFFFF )
  • color name ( cyan )
  • transparent
Parameters:
color The style element to change.
value The string representation of the color to set the style element to.

Florence::setFont ( QString  font  ) 

Sets the font of the symbols.

Changes the font used to draw the key symbols.

Parameters:
font The name of the font.

Florence::setKeymap ( QString  file  ) 

Sets the keymap of the keyboard.

Reads the keyboard keymap from the file.

Parameters:
file Name of the file that contains the XML description of the keymap.
Returns:
true on success and false on failure.

Florence::setLayout ( QString  file  ) 

Sets the layout of the keyboard.

Reads the keyboard layout from the file.

Parameters:
file Name of the file that contains the XML description of the layout.
Returns:
true on success and false on failure.

Florence::setOpacity ( qreal  opacity  ) 

Sets the keyboard opacity.

Only the background of the key's opacity is affecter by this function. This is a design decision so the labels of the key are always clearly visible.

Parameters:
opacity A number from 0.0 (transparent) to 1.0 (opaque)

Florence::setStyle ( QString  file  ) 

Sets the style of the keyboard.

Reads the keyboard style from the file.

Parameters:
file Name of the file that contains the XML description of the style.
Returns:
true on success and false on failure.

Florence::tab (  )  [signal]

Tab signal.

This signal is emitted when the Tab key has been activated. This can be used to move the focus to the next widget, or input a tab in the target widget.
